lines.text: Well, I wouldn't have missed meeting you for all the world. The first time I've gone slumming in years.
You win. You see in this racket, you learn to suspect the worst of everyone. The few times you are wrong, you have to apologize. I'm apologizing.
Well, thank you. I appreciate it.
You should. Humble pie gives me hives.
Oh, Bailey, you're about as subtle as a Mickey Finn.

[Pointing at Bailey]
This is a gun in my hand.
Yeah, I've seen one before.
You ask for trouble, you'll get it. I hired out for that job.
Who hired you?
You know what would happen to me if I told you?
The guy's tough, huh?
You can say that again.
Who's ever behind you is about as dangerous as a badminton's bird. Giving me that 200 bucks... that's right out of Aunt Sadie's hope chest.

[Jumps into Sharpy's car]
Let's talk.
Who are you?
I'm a guy who wants to talk. I'm lonely.
I gotta get outta here.
I wouldn't do that. Your friend upstairs might see you. Let's go up and join him. Maybe he's lonely too.
Well, what'll it be? Clam chowder or clam chowder?
Got any clam chowder?
Oh, that's special. Cost you extra.
So you're trying to find Janie.
Yeah.
That was all of six years ago, chum. What's your angle on her?
Oh, just leg work and the expense account is lean and hungry.
What's the information worth?
What's the information?

[Buster doesn't respond; Bailey pulls out some money]
What'll that buy?

[to Bailey]
Were you ever mixed up in a murder before? I'll let you in on something. To the bunco squad or the vice squad that license of yours may mean something. To the homicide bureau, it's just a scrap of paper.
You ever have the feeling you've been watched or followed?
Not nearly enough.
Well, come in.
[Norma walks into Bailey's office]
Is this love or were you looking for a detective?
Isn't there any other alternative?
Yes, but I haven't got time for it.
Can't you smell a frame-up when it's hanging under your nose?
Not when you're the man who's hanging it there.

[Covering up her bathing suit]
Please excuse my appearance. I... I was sunbathing.

[Smiling]
Don't let me interrupt.
Hello, Mr. B.
You're a sight for sore eyes.

[Notices Bailey has been beaten up]
You're a sight period!
You're just the man I wanted to see, Mr. Johnson. You got to get your wife up here.
My wife? Why?
Because I'm dancing on a hot griddle and she's going to get me off.

[Notices the name tag on her waitress uniform]
Just coffee, Millie.
My name ain't Millie. Millie got fired. My name's Fannie.
Fannie, would you remember...
I hate people that call me that.
But you just said your name was...
My friends call me Jackie.
Well, Jackie, would you remember...
I said my friends call me Jackie. To you I'm Miss Phipps.
Your name is Phipps.
Certainly. You know you oughta learn to get along with people. I see somebody shot 'cha.
Miss Phipps, you are what I call an observant woman.
You know, I'm the kind of a guy who can admit he's been a dope.
And I'm the kind of a gal that can go for a dope like you.

[to Sharpy and Herb]
You see, boys? He's a fanatic. He won't talk to me.
[He slugs Bailey]
Take it easy, Reno. You trying to kill him? He's gotta be in condition to talk.
The guy's a fanatic. You can't talk to fanatics. Fanatics won't talk!
Good morning.
Good morning.

[Noticing he was beat up]
Say, what happened to you? Are you the drunk they told me was sleeping it off upstairs?
Yeah, that's me.
I must have been hearing things. I thought they said it was a gal.
When I drink, my voice gets high.

[Barges through Bailey's door]
Someone downtown was having a joke - said you have some information for me.
Let's try this entrance again. You knock and I'll open the door.

[Points to Bailey lying unconscious on the bed]
There he is, Gracie. Pretty, huh?
Is he out?
Like a string of Christmas lights.
Let me go!

[Grabbing her shoulders]
Listen, I've been burned before. I've been given a high-class hotfoot with a gold-plated lighter. Either you're phony or most of my facts are. I'm still trying to find out which.

[to Bailey as she gets off the phone]
I throw them angles and they toss back curves.
